t: Send*pn lambs to the ruler of the land, from*ln Sela in the desert to*ln the mountain of Daughter Zion.
Like*ln a bird fleeing, forced*ln from the nest, the*ln daughters of Moab will*ln be at the fords of the Arnon.
Give*ln us counsel and make a decision. Shelter*ln us at noonday with*ln shade that is as dark as night. Hide*ln the refugees; do*ln not betray the one who flees.
Let*ln my refugees stay with you; be*ln a refuge for Moab from the aggressor. When*ln the oppressor has gone, destruction*ln has ended, and*ln marauders have vanished from the land,
a*pn throne will be established in love, and*ln one will sit on it faithfully in*ln the tent of David, judging*ln and pursuing what is right, quick*ln to execute justice.
We*ln have heard of Moab’s pride— how*ln very proud he is — his*ln haughtiness, his pride, his arrogance, and*ln his empty boasting.
Therefore*ln let Moab wail; let*ln every one of them wail for Moab. You*ln who are completely devastated, mourn for*ln the raisin cakes of Kir-hareseth.

For*ln Heshbon’s terraced vineyards and*ln the grapevines of Sibmah have withered. The*ln rulers of the nations have*ln trampled its choice vines that*ln reached as far as Jazer and*ln spread to the desert. Their*ln shoots spread out and*ln reached the sea.
So*ln I join with Jazer to*ln weep for the vines of Sibmah; I*ln drench Heshbon and Elealeh with my tears. Triumphant*ln shouts have fallen silent over*ln your summer fruit and your harvest.
Joy*ln and rejoicing have been removed from the orchard; no*ln one is singing or shouting for joy in the vineyards. No*ln one tramples grapes in the winepresses. I*ln have put an end to the shouting.
Therefore*pn I moan like the sound of a lyre for Moab, as*ln does my innermost being for Kir-heres.
When*ln Moab appears and*ln tires himself out on the high place and*ln comes to his sanctuary to pray, it*ln will do him no good.
This*p is the message that the Lord*s previously announced about Moab.

And now the Lord*s says, “In three years, as a hired worker counts years, Moab’s splendor will become an object of contempt, in spite of a very large population. And those who are left will be few and weak.”
